awd_titl_txt: Femtosecond Studies of the Influence of Solvent on Chemical Reaction Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure Dynamics and Mechanism (CDSM-A) program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Stephen Bradforth of the University of Southern California is using photo-electron spectroscopy (PES) and other laser-based techniques to study the structure of liquid ammonia.  PES is a technique that uses light to remove electrons from an atom or molecule. By measuring the energy of these electrons, information can be obtained about the structure of the molecule as well as its interactions with other nearby molecules.  The Bradforth group is also studying what happens to the interactions between ammonia molecules when extra electrons are dissolved in the liquid.  Liquid ammonia was chosen because it can dissolve higher concentrations of electrons, is similar to water in its structure, and because ammonia is relevant to a number of important industrial processes. Since the PES technique involves removal of electrons from molecules caused by light, the research may also provide insights into similar processes such as the damage to living cells caused by light (for example, during cancer radiation therapy). Students and postdocs involved in the project receive training in building instrumentation for new instruments and benefit from training in international labs. As part of the broader impact of this project, Professor Bradforth is continuing an outreach project that provides hands-on summer internships for students from Cerritos College, a minority-serving community college.

This research project explores the electronic structure of the hydrogen-bonding liquid ammonia, and the relationship of this structure to that of water. A central focus of the project is to establish how the electronic density of states can be manipulated by solute dopants. The specific objectives of the project are: (i) to determine the liquid valence band orbital delocalization from experimental photoelectron spectroscopy (PES) and photoelectron angular distribution (PAD) measurements; (ii) to identify isolated solvated electrons, spin-paired dielectrons, and the metal-insulator transition at high excess electron concentration using pump-probe PES measurements of liquid ammonia containing solvated electrons (supplied by alkali metals), and (iii) to characterize low-lying conduction band states and their coupling to localized molecular doorway states using continuous two-photon absorption spectroscopy. The transient absorption and photoelectron spectroscopy work is being done in Professor Bradforth's laboratory at USC. The angle-resolved tunable X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (PAD) studies are being conducted at the Hamburg and Berlin synchrotron light sources.

por.por_cntn:
Under grant 1665532, the Bradforth group has extensively developed and exploited a newly emerging experimental technique in physical chemistry, liquid jet photoelectron spectroscopy.  This approach opens up for new understanding the weakly bound valence electrons of solutes when these reactants are dissolved in the common liquid solvents used for organic synthesis.  The larger context for our project is that while electronic structure (knowledge of the solute molecular orbitals) controls chemical reactivity, it is not usually read out directly for molecular transformations happening in the real environments where chemistry is practiced.   Photoelectron spectroscopy provides direct access to a molecule’s electrons, their binding energies and shapes, but has hitherto only been possible for isolated molecules and for solid surfaces in vacuum.  

 

The liquid microjet technique introduced only 20 years ago, has almost entirely been used for aqueous solutions; the technique is not yet mature and many wrinkles are being worked out.  Working with collaborators in Berlin and Prague, we have dramatically extended the technique to common organic solvents such as tetrahydrofuran and acetonitrile, and more exotic cooled liquids like liquid ammonia.  The latter solvent is regularly used synthetically for the regioselective Birch reductions of aromatics like benzene.  A landmark study from this project showed how the localization of excess electrons in liquid ammonia, which are used as reactants in the Birch reduction, evolves from dilute electrolyte to liquid metal state with increasing concentration.  An explicit spectral evolution provides direct visualization of a change from electrons pairing up in liquid cavities to electrons freely percolating throughout the liquid network. Building on this work, we discovered that water itself could be heavily doped with excess electrons to become metallic: optical and photoelectron spectra showed that a liquid water film coating a droplet had a band structure characteristic of a dilute metal.  

 

In further experiments using the synchrotron source in Berlin, we were also able to show how the occupied molecular orbitals of the solvent itself changed on condensation to a liquid via photoelectron spectroscopy. A different technique was used in our lab for common liquid solvents in parallel: coherent two-photon absorption spectroscopy which probes the unoccupied orbitals that make up the conduction band.

 

Subsequent photoelectron experiments allowed us to directly read out the electronic structure for a later critical intermediate in the Birch reduction - determining how the frontier orbital electrons are bound in two radical anion intermediates in the reduction of naphthalene and benzophenone. The experiments also characterized the molecular orbital picture for the reaction medium, liquid tetrahydrofuran, for the first time. Combined with state-of-the-art theory, we could explain how such intermediates are critically stabilized by the specific electrostatic environment of the liquid reaction medium and map out part of the reaction coordinate.  Ongoing work explores the influence of the specific interaction of counter cations.

 

The award has enabled training at the state of the art in physical chemistry, from one postdoctoral, four doctoral, three undergraduate and four community college students – the latter group through a summer internship program aimed at broadening participation.  The project has included many instrumental advances, strongly leveraging an international travel supplement that has allowed student training in two laboratories in Germany. Instrumentation advances have ranged from new sources for highly reactive cooled solutions, development of new approaches to measuring binding energies with higher efficiency and resolution, and to capture the spatial distribution of ejected electrons. The project has tackled head on major challenges for photoelectron spectroscopy of liquids that have emerged, namely the smearing out of vital binding energy information because of inelastic energy loss as the electrons emerge from the liquid and the effect of elastic scattering on angular information.  Strategies have been developed to mitigate these problems which suggest that this technique will become increasingly important in the physical chemistry of solution chemistry.
